column1: Mill Creek is a city in Snohomish County
column3: United States. It is located between the cities of Everett and Lynnwood
column4: approximately 20 miles (32 km) northeast of Seattle. The city has a population of 18
column6: and is estimated to have over 20

column1: The city is one of the wealthiest suburbs in the Seattle metropolitan area and was originally a planned community conceived in the 1970s. The planned development was centered around a country club and golf course
column2: with other development occurring nearby in later phases. It was incorporated as a city in 1983
column3: shortly after the completion of the first phase of development
column4: and underwent major population growth due to continued suburban development and annexation of nearby areas. The city's downtown area is centered around the Mill Creek Town Center
column5: a mixed-use lifestyle center and retail complex that opened in 2004.

column1: The Mill Creek area was originally settled in the early 20th century by various farming families
column2: from whom several local placenames are now derived. After the construction of the Bothell–Everett Highway in 1913 as part of the Pacific Highway
column3: two junctions at Murphy's Corner and Wintermute's Corner gained small stores and gas stations to serve visitors. In 1931
column4: Doctor Manch N. Garhart acquired 800 acres (320 ha) in the area and used it to grow Gravenstein apples and Bartlett pears while also raising cattle. The Garhart property
column5: named Lake Dell Farm for a small reservoir built by local families
column6: was later sold in 1967 to real estate developers after the market for local lumber and fruits had declined.The Garhart property
column8: were optioned by various real estate developers in the 1960s and 1970s as a potential master planned community due to its proximity to the recently completed Interstate 5. It would be the first modern planned city in Washington state
column9: following in the footsteps of earlier planned cities like Longview

column2: Mill Creek drafted a comprehensive plan that would transform its newly-annexed commercial area into a mixed-use downtown area to support the growing city. The 23-acre (9.3 ha) downtown development would include a large public park
column6: and office buildings. After difficulty in finding a suitable developer
column7: the Mill Creek Town Center began construction in 2001 and the first phase opened three years later. The second phase was completed in 2007

The project also included new bus stops that were later upgraded with the opening of the Swift Green Line bus rapid transit system in March 2019.The city government began planning for a second urban village

column1: The city of Mill Creek has a total area of 4.69 square miles (12.15 km2) according to the U.S. Census Bureau. The city limits of Mill Creek are generally defined to the west by North Creek
column2: to the north by 132nd Street Southeast (part of State Route 96) and Everett
column3: to the east by Seattle Hill Road and 35th Avenue Southeast
column4: and to the south by 163rd Street Southeast and North Creek County Park. The city is surrounded by a larger urban growth area that encompasses  unincorporated land
column5: including the communities of Martha Lake and Silver Firs
column7: 171 people in 2014. The urban growth area extends west to Interstate 5
column8: including an overlapping claim with Lynnwood and south to 196th Street Southeast at the north end of the Bothell claim.Several creeks flow through the city
column9: including North Creek (a tributary of the Sammamish River)
column11: and Nickel Creek. A minor stream known as Smokehouse Creek was renamed to Mill Creek in 2001
column12: retroactively giving the city a geographic namesake. The center of Mill Creek lies along State Route 527
column13: between two protected wetlands along North Creek and Penny Creek. The original plat of Mill Creek
column15: consists of 21 neighborhood subdivisions that are named for various types of trees.

column2: Mill Creek has an estimated workforce population of 10
column3: 227 people and an unemployment rate of 2.2 percent. The largest industry of employment for Mill Creek residents is in educational services and health care
column7: and retail trade (12%). Approximately 3 percent of the city's workers have jobs located within city limits
column8: with the majority commuting to employers in other cities
column9: with an average commute time of 31 minutes. Over 21 percent of workers commute to Seattle
column13: and Bothell (5%).The Puget Sound Regional Council estimated that the city had a total of 6
column15: with the largest sectors being professional services and construction. Mill Creek's largest employers include Albertsons
column20: and the Mill Creek County Club. The city was formerly the headquarters of video games developer Handheld Games and food manufacturer Dream Dinners.

column1: Mill Creek is a non-charter code city with a council–manager government. The city council is composed of seven members elected in non-partisan
column2: at-large elections to four-year terms. The councilmembers elect a ceremonial mayor and mayor pro tem from its members and appoint a city manager to execute its legislative policies. The current mayor is councilman Brian Holtzclaw
column3: who was appointed in 2020 after the mid-term resignation of Pam Pruitt. The city manager is Michael Ciaravino
column4: who was appointed in May 2019 after the position was held by an interim manager for a year.The city government has approximately 65 employees and a biennial appropriations budget of $59 million. Mill Creek provides civil services through its departments
column8: and public works. Several services are also contracted out to regional agencies and private companies
column11: and fire protection. The city hall is located at the Huntron Building
column12: which was acquired by the city government in 2008 and is located adjacent to the former city office building.At the federal level
column13: Mill Creek has been part of the 1st congressional district since 2012 and is represented by Democrat Suzan DelBene of Medina. At the state level
column14: the city is part of the 44th legislative district alongside Lake Stevens and Snohomish. Mill Creek is also part of the Snohomish County Council's 4th district
column17: and Mountlake Terrace; the district is represented by Jared Mead
column18: a former Mill Creek city councilman and state legislator who was appointed in 2020.

column1: Mill Creek hosts a twice-annual community garage sale in May and October that was permitted by the covenants of the original development. The event
column2: one of the largest of its kind in the county
column3: brings an influx of outside traffic and is also coordinated with charity donations. The city's chamber of commerce has an annual festival in July
column4: while the town center has weekly concerts during the summertime. The city also hosts annual parades on Memorial Day and Veterans Day. Mill Creek's farmers market runs from June to August and is located in the city hall parking lot.

column1: Mill Creek has ten parks and two other recreational facilities maintained by the city government and located within city limits
column2: comprising a total of 43 acres (17 ha). The city's ten neighborhood parks include playgrounds
column4: and picnic tables; they range in size from the 1.2-acre (0.49 ha) Library Park to the 19.75-acre (7.99 ha) Nickel Creek Park. The Mill Creek Sports Park is a 4.8-acre (1.9 ha) park with a multi-purpose field for baseball
column7: along with stands and a skate park.The county government has several parks and recreational facilities near Mill Creek
column8: including McCollum Park on State Route 96
column9: Martha Lake Park to the west of the city
column10: and North Creek Park at the south end of the city. McCollum Park and North Creek Park are connected to Mill Creek by a north–south multi-use pathway
column12: which continues south to Bothell. Mill Creek and the county also share joint ownership of Tambark Creek Park
column13: located southeast of the city.The golf course at the center of the original Mill Creek subdivision is owned by the members of the private country club
column14: who purchased the facility for $5.2 million in 2007. The golf course is 300 yards (270 m) short of the required length to host a professional men's tournament. Mill Creek also has a private indoor sports arena that opened in 2017

column1: Mill Creek is served by several community publications
column2: including the twice-monthly Mill Creek Beacon
column3: the weekly News of Mill Creek
column4: and the quarterly Mill Creek Living magazine. The Beacon was founded in 2014 and is owned by Beacon Publishing
column5: which also operates weekly newspapers in Edmonds and Mukilteo. A regional weekly newspaper
column7: formerly published a Mill Creek edition until a consolidation in 2009.The city's public library was constructed in 1987 and expanded several times by Sno-Isle Libraries
column8: its operator. Due to overcrowding at the current building
column9: the city government considered a proposal to build a new library atop a Target store in the East Gateway urban village

column1: Public education in Mill Creek is provided by Everett Public Schools
column2: which serves the adjacent city of Everett and several unincorporated neighborhoods. The school district covers 52 square miles (130 km2) and has a total enrollment of more than 20
column3: 200 students. Mill Creek and its surrounding urban growth area is home to seven of the school district's 32 schools: Henry M. Jackson High School
column6: and four elementary schools. The area also has several private schools
column7: including Archbishop Murphy High School and Cedar Park Christian School. The nearest post-secondary institution is University of Washington Bothell
column8: which draws students from southern Snohomish County.

column1: Mill Creek lies east of Interstate 5
column2: the main north–south freeway through the Seattle metropolitan area with connections to Downtown Seattle and Everett. The city is bisected from north to south by State Route 527 (the Bothell–Everett Highway)
column3: which continues to Bothell. The two highways are connected by a pair of east–west streets
column5: which continue further east into the residential neighborhoods of Mill Creek and towards State Route 9.The city's public transportation is provided by Community Transit
column6: which also serves most of the county
column7: and consists of several local and commuter bus routes. The county's second bus rapid transit route
column9: travels along State Route 527 and has several stops in Mill Creek
column10: connecting the city to Paine Field and northern Bothell; a third bus rapid transit route
column12: is planned to open in 2024 to connect Mill Creek to Link light rail at Lynnwood Transit Center. Other local routes connect Mill Creek to Everett
column16: two commuter routes connect the State Route 527 and 132nd Street corridors to Downtown Seattle. The Ash Way Park and Ride is located west of the Mill Creek Town Center and has additional connections to Community Transit and Sound Transit Express routes. A Link light rail extension to Everett is planned to open in 2036 with stations at Ash Way and Mariner Park and Ride near Mill Creek.A private airfield
column18: operated west of modern-day Mill Creek from 1953 to 1998. It has since been converted into a county park
column19: after the owners rejected a proposal to develop it into a housing subdivision. The nearest commercial airport is Paine Field
column20: located 3 miles (4.8 km) northwest in Everett.

column1: Electric power in Mill Creek is provided by the Snohomish County Public Utility District (PUD)
column2: a consumer-owned public utility that serves all of Snohomish County. Puget Sound Energy provides natural gas service to the city's residents and businesses. The city government has a contract with Waste Management for curbside garbage
column4: and yard waste collection and disposal.The city's tap water and sewage systems are split between the Alderwood Water and Wastewater District and the Silver Lake Water and Sewer District
column5: two independent municipal corporations. Both water districts use the Spada Lake reservoir
column6: the main source of water for Snohomish County
column7: and send wastewater to the Brightwater plant in Maltby and a facility in Everett.

column1: Mill Creek is located near an urgent care center operated by Swedish Medical Center
column2: which opened in 2011 and has an emergency room and other services. The Everett Clinic opened a 6
column4: offering walk-in and community services. An urgent care center operated by EvergreenHealth opened in 2018 with an on-site laboratory and nine exam rooms. Seattle Children's Hospital also operated a children's health clinic in Mill Creek until 2018
column5: when it was replaced by a countywide facility adjacent to Everett's Providence Regional Medical Center.
